readings: Commissioner Lin's Letter to Queen Victoria

readingAnalyses.title: Commissioner Lin's Letter to Queen Victoria
readingAnalyses.author: Lin Zexu (林則徐)
readingAnalyses.source: The Chinese Repository, vol. VIII, no. 10 (February 1840)
readingAnalyses.summary: Lin Zexu's 1839 letter to Queen Victoria is a masterpiece of moral argumentation wrapped in the rhetoric of the Chinese world order. As Imperial Commissioner sent to Canton to suppress the opium trade, Lin appeals to universal principles of justice and reciprocity: 'We have heard that in your own country opium is prohibited with the utmost strictness and severity—this is a strong proof that you know full well how hurtful it is to mankind.' He argues that Britain, having benefited enormously from trade with China for 200 years, should not repay this generosity with poison. The letter reveals both Qing confidence ('Our celestial empire rules over ten thousand kingdoms!') and genuine bewilderment that a nation claiming to be civilized would traffic in drugs.

keyQuotes.quote: We have heard that in your own country opium is prohibited with the utmost strictness and severity:—this is a strong proof that you know full well how hurtful it is to mankind. Since then you do not permit it to injure your own country, you ought not to have the injurious drug transferred to another country.

By what principle of reason then, should these foreigners send in return a poisonous drug, which involves in destruction those very natives of China? Without meaning to say that the foreigners harbor such destructive intentions in their hearts, we yet positively assert that from their inordinate thirst after gain, they are perfectly careless about the injuries they inflict upon us!

Let us suppose that foreigners came from another country, and brought opium into England, and seduced the people of your country to smoke it, would not you, the sovereign of the said country, look upon such a procedure with anger, and in your just indignation endeavor to get rid of it?
Our celestial empire rules over ten thousand kingdoms! Most surely do we possess a measure of godlike majesty which ye cannot fathom!

thematicExamples: The Golden Rule argument: Lin explicitly invokes reciprocity—'you are incapable of doing or causing to be done unto another, that which you should not wish another to do unto you'
The tributary system worldview: Lin treats Britain as a respectful tributary that has benefited from Chinese benevolence, not as an equal power

Economic interdependence argument: Lin points out that Chinese goods (tea, silk, rhubarb) are necessities for Britain, while Western goods are 'only calculated to make presents of, or serve for mere amusement'

Legal sovereignty claim: 'Suppose the subject of another country were to come to England to trade, he would certainly be required to comply with the laws of England, then how much more does this apply to us of the celestial empire!'
realLifeConnections: Contemporary fentanyl crisis: The roles are now reversed—China is accused of allowing precursor chemicals to flow to North America. How would Americans respond to a Chinese official's letter telling us to just stop using drugs?

Corporate responsibility: Lin argues that even if merchants don't intend harm, their 'inordinate thirst after gain' makes them 'perfectly careless about the injuries they inflict.' This echoes debates about tobacco, opioid manufacturers, social media companies.
The letter was never delivered to Victoria—British officials intercepted it. What does it mean when one side's communication is simply ignored?
Diplomatic asymmetry: Lin writes in the language of universal morality; Britain responds with gunboats. This pattern repeats throughout modern history.

readingAnalyses.title: Treaty of Nanjing
readingAnalyses.author: British and Qing Plenipotentiaries
readingAnalyses.source: Encyclopedia of Historical Treaties and Alliances
readingAnalyses.summary: The Treaty of Nanjing (August 29, 1842) ended the First Opium War and became the template for all subsequent 'unequal treaties' imposed on China. Its 13 articles forced China to: (1) cede Hong Kong 'in perpetuity,' (2) open five 'treaty ports' to British residence and trade, (3) pay $21 million in indemnities—including $6 million compensation for the opium Lin Zexu had destroyed, (4) abolish the Canton trade monopoly (Co-hong), and (5) establish extraterritoriality (British subjects tried only in British consular courts). Crucially, the treaty never legalized opium—Britain achieved all its goals while maintaining the fiction that the war was about 'free trade,' not narcotics.

keyQuotes.quote: His Majesty the Emperor of China cedes to Her Majesty the Queen of Great Britain, &c., the Island of Hong-Kong, to be possessed in perpetuity by Her Britannic Majesty, her heirs and successors.

The Emperor of China agrees to pay the sum of 6,000,000 of dollars, as the value of the opium which was delivered up at Canton in the month of March, 1839, as a ransom for the lives of Her Britannic Majesty's Superintendent and subjects, who had been imprisoned and threatened with death by the Chinese High Officers.

British subjects, with their families and establishments, shall be allowed to reside, for the purposes of carrying on their mercantile pursuits, without molestation or restraint, at the cities and towns of Canton, Amoy, Foochowfoo, Ningpo, and Shanghai.

The Government of Her Britannic Majesty having been obliged to send out an expedition to demand and obtain redress for the violent and unjust proceedings of the Chinese High Authorities towards Her Britannic Majesty's officer and subjects, the Emperor of China agrees to pay the sum of 12,000,000 of dollars, on account of the expences incurred.

thematicExamples: Indemnity for confiscated drugs: Article IV makes China pay for the opium Lin destroyed—as if the victim must compensate the drug dealer
War costs charged to the loser: Article VI requires China to pay Britain's military expenses—the costs of being invaded
Extraterritoriality implied but not spelled out here—formalized in supplementary Treaty of the Bogue (1843)
The treaty was signed aboard HMS Cornwallis at Nanjing—the location itself (where the Grand Canal meets the Yangzi) showed British ability to strike at China's economic heart
realLifeConnections: Hong Kong's 1997 return: The 'in perpetuity' cession was ended when the 99-year lease on the New Territories expired. China explicitly framed the return as healing the wound of national humiliation.
Extraterritoriality today: US military bases abroad often have 'Status of Forces Agreements' granting legal immunity. Is this different?
Trade agreements and power: 'Most favored nation' clauses now appear in WTO agreements, but with different implications when power is more equal.
The treaty said nothing about opium—Britain got everything it wanted while maintaining moral deniability. How do modern powers achieve controversial goals through neutral-sounding legal language?

overallSynthesis:
These two documents form a devastating pair: Lin Zexu's eloquent moral appeal followed by the brutal legal machinery of imposed defeat. Read together, they explode any simple narrative of East-West encounter.

Lin's letter shows that Qing China was neither isolated nor incapable of sophisticated diplomacy. His arguments—reciprocity, universal ethics, mutual benefit—are exactly what we'd expect from a rational actor in international relations. He even anticipates counterarguments, noting that Britain's own laws prove opium's danger. This wasn't a 'backward' empire failing to understand the modern world; it was a principled stance that happened to lack the military power to enforce it.

The Treaty of Nanjing reveals how 'free trade' ideology served imperial interests. Notice what the treaty doesn't contain: any mention of opium. Britain achieved all its commercial and territorial goals while pretending the war was about trade restrictions and diplomatic insults, not drug trafficking. The legalistic language—'peace and friendship,' 'full security and protection'—masks what is essentially a protection racket: pay us, open your markets, cede territory, or we'll burn more cities.

For the course narrative, these readings mark the moment when the East Asian world order definitively cracked. Qianlong could dismiss Macartney in 1793 because Qing power was real; fifty years later, that power proved hollow against British naval technology. The question isn't whether this was morally wrong (it clearly was) but what combination of factors—economic, technological, institutional—had shifted the balance so dramatically.
executiveSummary:
Plate 10 examines the First Opium War (1839-1842) through two primary sources that expose the moral asymmetry of Western imperialism. Lin Zexu's letter to Queen Victoria makes a compelling case against the opium trade using universal principles: if Britain bans opium at home, how can it sell poison abroad? 'Let us suppose that foreigners came from another country, and brought opium into England... would not you, the sovereign of the said country, look upon such a procedure with anger?'

The letter never reached Victoria. Instead, Britain sent gunboats, and the resulting Treaty of Nanjing forced China to cede Hong Kong, open five treaty ports, pay $21 million (including compensation for destroyed opium!), and submit to extraterritoriality. The treaty's neutral legal language conceals its nature as an imposed settlement—China paying for the privilege of being invaded.

These readings begin China's 'century of humiliation' and establish patterns that would define East Asian history: unequal treaties, treaty ports, foreign enclaves, and the burning question of how to respond to Western power.

keywords.relevance: Immediate cause of war; revealed limits of Qing sovereignty over its own territory

keywords.definition: Treaties imposed on China (and later Japan, Korea) granting Western powers special privileges without reciprocity
keywords.relevance: Defined China's international status for a century; abolishing them became central nationalist goal

keywords.relevance: Became semi-colonial spaces with foreign concessions; also sites of modernization

keywords.definition: Foreign nationals subject only to their own consular courts, not local law
keywords.relevance: Symbol of humiliation—implied Chinese legal system was inferior; not fully abolished until 1943

people: Lin Zexu (林則徐) — Imperial Commissioner; destroyed 20,283 chests of opium; wrote letter to Victoria
Queen Victoria — British monarch (letter never delivered to her)
Daoguang Emperor (道光帝) — Qing ruler who 'quivered with indignation' upon hearing of opium crisis
places: Canton (Guangzhou 廣州) — Center of opium trade; Lin destroyed opium here in June 1839
Hong Kong (香港) — 'Barren rock' ceded to Britain 'in perpetuity'; returned 1997
Nanjing (南京) — Where treaty was signed aboard HMS Cornwallis, August 1842
things: Opium (鴉片) — Drug grown in British India, smuggled to China, creating millions of addicts
Treaty of Nanjing — First 'unequal treaty'; template for subsequent concessions
Co-hong (公行) — Canton merchant monopoly abolished by treaty; opened trade to competition

keyQuestions.question: 'Let us suppose that foreigners came from another country and brought opium into England...' — Why didn't Lin's moral argument work?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Lin's argument was logically sound but power trumped logic. The letter was never delivered. Britain framed the war as about 'free trade' and 'diplomatic insults.' Having the better argument means nothing without power to enforce it. Discuss: when do moral arguments actually change policy?

keyQuestions.question: The Treaty of Nanjing made China pay $6 million for the opium Lin destroyed. What does this reveal about 'international law' in the 19th century?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: International law was what powerful states said it was. The payment frames Lin's action as theft rather than law enforcement. Notice the treaty never legalizes opium—Britain got everything without admitting what the war was really about. How does legal language obscure power relations today?

keyQuestions.question: Why is this called the start of China's 'century of humiliation'? Why does it still matter in 2026?
keyQuestions.talkingPoints: Hong Kong's 1997 return was explicitly framed as ending this humiliation. Taiwan, South China Sea, resistance to 'interference'—all invoke this memory. Chinese leaders reference it to justify assertive foreign policy. Is the narrative productive (preserving historical memory) or problematic (perpetuating grievance)?

timeline.event: Macartney Mission—Qianlong rejects British requests, but no war follows
Lin Zexu destroys 20,283 chests of opium at Canton; writes letter to Victoria
First Opium War—British naval superiority crushes Qing resistance
Treaty of Nanjing signed aboard HMS Cornwallis (August 29)
Second Opium War—more concessions; Summer Palace burned
Hong Kong returned to China—'perpetuity' ended at 155 years

connections.fromPrevious: Plate 9 was brainstorming. But Plates 6-8 showed Qing confidence (Qianlong's letter) and Tokugawa stability. Now we see that confidence shattered—what changed in 50 years?
connections.toNext: Plate 11 examines Japan's similar encounter: Commodore Perry's 'Black Ships' (1853) demanded the same 'opening.' Why did Japan avoid the worst features of unequal treaties longer than China?
connections.broaderThemes: The Opium War initiated a fundamental reordering of East Asia's relationship with the West. Every subsequent reform movement—Self-Strengthening, Hundred Days, revolutionary nationalism—responded to this shock.

nextPreview.preview: Perry's Black Ships arrive in 1853. Japan faces the same Western pressure that humiliated China—but responds with the Harris Treaty (1858) and daimyo debates about how to handle the 'barbarians.'

teachingNotes: Read Lin Zexu's 'suppose foreigners brought opium into England' passage aloud—it's the most powerful moment in the letter. Then ask: why didn't this argument work?
The Treaty of Nanjing is short enough to read key articles in class. Have students identify: what does China give up? What does it get? (Nothing.)
Connect to fentanyl crisis: China is now accused of enabling drug flows to the West. How would Americans respond to a Chinese official's lecture about morality?
Show map of treaty ports—help students visualize what 'unequal treaties' meant spatially. These weren't abstract concepts but foreign enclaves on Chinese soil.
Avoid simplistic framing but don't 'both-sides' a drug war. Lin was right; Britain was a state-backed drug cartel. Complexity lies in why Qing was vulnerable, not in moral equivalence.
